Award.AwardTitle: CAREER:Understanding Sponteneous Combustion of Hydrogen and Oxygen in Nanobubbles

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

1254648
Qiao, Li

The proposed study is focused on ignition and combustion of hydrogen and oxygen in nano-sized confinements formed by water nano-bubbles, which are generated by electrolysis. It is hypothesized that ignition and combustion results from either (1) the confinement shortening the effective mean free path resulting in higher rates of molecular collision, reaction, and heat release to overcome the significant heat loss commonly encountered in small combustion devices, or (2) the pressure increase during the collapse of the water bubble resembling that in a rapid compression machine that leads to ignition and combustion of the reactant mixture. Experimental efforts concentrate on measurements of bubble size, growth dynamics, and temperature within the bubble. Scanning laser-Doppler vibrometry is used for determining bubble size and evolution, while micro fabrication techniques are used to produce nano-scale thermometer suitable for the associated small time and spatial length scales. The study is aimed at bridging the gap between nano-science and traditional combustion science that are usually associated with systems of much larger scales such as engines. Potential benefits include understanding ignition and combustion at truly nano-scales, with applications in small energy systems and machinery and fire safety. A Molecular Dynamics approach is adopted for determining the pressure and chemical reactions of the H2/O2 mixture within the nano-bubble To help alleviate the difficulties in the proposed small-scale experiments. The educational program calls for education of the public, dissemination of research through a popular nano-science website, research opportunities for undergraduate students, and recruitment and mentoring of woman engineering graduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Combustion of fuels has been a prominent means of providing energy with a wide range of applications in energy, transportation, defense, and space exploration. Typical combustion devices such as internal combustion engines, gas turbines and rockets are macroscopic systems with lengths on the order of meters. Combustion devices that have smaller length scales, such as mesoscale and microscale, are rare. Studies on combustion on the scale of nanometers is even sparse. Recently, researchers in the Netherlands accidentally discovered spontaneous combustion of hydrogen and oxygen mixtures in nanosized bubbles generated by water eletrolysis. Of even greater interest, they discovered that combustion did not take place in microsized bubbles; it happened only when the size was below a critical value of about 200 nanometers. Because this is the only experiment that suggested combustion took place in a nanoscale device (nanobubbles created by water electrolysis), the first question is – did combustion really happen in those nanobubbles? How could we approve it? If this is true, then the second question is - why can combustion take place in nanobubbles but not in microbubbles?

 

Motivated by the above questions, the major goal of this project was to understand if spontaneous combustion can take place in nanobubbles and if so, what are the mechanisms responsible for this behavior. The combined experiments based on microscale fabrication techniques and molecular dynamics simulations have provided several important insights on the nanobubble combustion phenomenon. The ﬁndings of our experimental work conﬁrmed the occurrence of combustion inside the nanobubbles generated by water electrolysis. Based on the simulation results, we learned that the internal pressure inside a nanobubble is much smaller than what would have been predicted using the planar interface surface tension value of water based on the Laplace-Young question. Nevertheless, the pressures were still very high, which could provide a suitable environment for the spontaneous ignition and combustion to occur. Additionally, we learned that in the low-temperature and high-pressure environment like in a nanobubble, the chemical reaction pathway can be very different from that at macroscopic combustion conditions which are at high temperatures and low-to-moderate pressures. Lastly, we learned that the radicals, generated by surface dissociation of hydrogen and oxygen, can promote chemical reactions. In summary, what we learned from the simulations qualitatively explained the experimental observations. The new physics of combustion in nanobubbles may tantalize us to investigate the many potential applications of this concept lying in the areas of nanostructured combustion for nano- or microengines, nanoheater devices, and so on.
